intro: Hi there, budding scientist! Let's explore the fascinating world of how heat travels. Think of it like a game of tag, where heat energy always runs from the 'hotter' player to the 'colder' one!

questions.question: Imagine you have a mug of hot cocoa and a cold glass of juice. If you accidentally touch both, which one will feel hotter to your hand, and why?
options: A) The hot cocoa, because heat flows from the cocoa to your hand.
B) The cold juice, because heat flows from your hand to the juice.
C) Both feel the same because heat doesn't really move.
D) The hot cocoa, because your hand is colder than the cocoa.
questions.hint: Remember the description of heat flow. Where does heat prefer to go?

questions.question: When you hold a piece of ice, your hand starts to feel cold. What is actually happening with the heat energy in this situation?
options: A) Heat is moving from the ice to your hand, making your hand colder.
B) Heat is moving from your hand to the ice, making the ice melt and your hand feel cold.
C) No heat is moving, your hand is just getting used to the cold.
D) Heat is being created by the ice.
questions.hint: Think about what temperature means. Is your hand hotter or colder than the ice?

questions.question: Why do we wear woolen clothes in winter to stay warm?
options: A) Woolen clothes produce their own heat.
B) Woolen clothes allow heat to flow easily from our bodies to the cold air.
C) Woolen clothes trap our body heat and prevent it from flowing out into the cold.
D) Woolen clothes make the air around us hotter.
questions.hint: Consider how heat moves and what it means for woolen clothes to be 'poor conductors'.

followups: Try touching a metal spoon and a wooden spoon that have been in the same room. Which feels colder, and why? (Hint: This relates to how easily different materials let heat flow through them!)
Think about a time you've felt hot and a time you've felt cold. Can you describe where the heat was flowing in each case?
summary: Heat is a form of energy that always travels from a hotter place to a colder place. This is why hot things cool down and cold things warm up when they are together. This fundamental idea helps us understand many everyday phenomena, from cooking to wearing the right clothes!
